title: Cross Domain WiFi Sensing with Channel State Information A Survey

bibliographic_data.title: AirFi: Empowering WiFi-based Passive Human Gesture Recognition to Unseen Environment via Domain Generalization
bibliographic_data.venue: Proceedings of the ACM on Interactive, Mobile, Wearable and Ubiquitous Technologies

algorithms: Domain generalization framework
Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD)
Adversarial training
Feature disentanglement
theoretical_contributions: First systematic domain generalization theory for WiFi gesture recognition
RKHS-based MMD distribution alignment
Convergence guarantees for cross-domain adaptation

breakthrough_points: Zero target domain data requirement
Cross-environment robustness across 4 environments
15-27% performance improvement over baselines

datasets_used: Custom multi-domain dataset: 8 gestures × 8 users × 4 environments = 6,400 samples

specific_applications: Cross-environment deployment challenges
Domain generalization theory in WiFi sensing
MMD-based distribution alignment
Adversarial learning applications

strengths: First systematic domain generalization framework for WiFi sensing
Strong mathematical foundation with RKHS theory
Comprehensive multi-environment validation
Significant performance improvements (15-27%)
Zero target domain data requirement
limitations: Limited to 4 indoor environments only
Small user sample size (8 volunteers)
MMD computational complexity O(n²)
Kernel function selection lacks theoretical guidance
Short-term experiments without long-term stability analysis
future_directions: Extension to outdoor and industrial environments
Large-scale user diversity validation
Lightweight MMD computation for edge deployment
Automated kernel function selection framework
Long-term deployment stability analysis

002.title: Robust WiFi Respiration Sensing in the Presence of Interfering Individual

dataset_analysis.data_collection_methodology: Multi-subject WiFi CSI collection in furnished laboratory
limitations: Limited to indoor environments
Requires phase calibration for commercial devices

model_architecture.core_innovation: Convex optimization-based beam control with respiratory energy analysis

key_components.name: Convex Optimization Beam Control
key_components.optimization_problem: arg min ||w - w_desired||² s.t. w^H a(θ_b, τ_b) = 1, w^H Q w ≤ β

key_components.name: Dual-Scenario Processing
key_components.description: Fixed area vs. random movement interference handling

model_architecture.computational_complexity: O(nAnτ · N log(N)/(k1 · k2)) with hierarchical search

test_scenarios.description: Interferer performs activities in fixed location

reproducibility_evaluation.hardware_requirements: Clearly specified for both professional and commercial devices

technical_innovations.significance: First quantitative analysis of interference impact on WiFi respiration sensing
Novel application of convex optimization for interference suppression in WiFi sensing
Intelligent handling of fixed vs. mobile interferer scenarios

limitations_and_future_work.description: Analysis limited to ULA, non-uniform arrays need modifications
Challenging localization when multiple interferers present
Real-time optimization burden in dynamic scenarios

application_domains: Smart home health sensing with family members present
Hospital patient monitoring with medical staff interference

overall_assessment.contribution_to_field: Significant breakthrough in robust WiFi sensing
overall_assessment.recommendation: Essential reading for WiFi sensing researchers

011.title: A Taxonomy of WiFi Sensing: CSI vs Passive WiFi Radar

activities: picking up small items from floor

data_collection.different_channels: systems on separate channels to avoid interference

processing_pipeline: Raw CSI data collection from WiFi preambles
csi_system.pca_components: 5 (discarded first component due to static noise)

processing_pipeline: Cross Ambiguity Function (CAF) for range-Doppler surface
CLEAN algorithm for direct signal interference suppression
Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) for noise reduction

per_activity_performance.other_activities: relatively low accuracy (varies by system and layout)

performance_results.classifier: Simple 2D CNN (1 conv + 1 max-pool + 2 FC layers)

csi_characteristics: Operates at subcarrier level with fine-grained features
Cannot determine movement direction (short integration time)
Results in 90k complex values per second
pwr_characteristics: Uses entire WiFi signal including time gaps
Treats OFDM signal as single entity
Can determine velocity and direction (longer integration time)
No knowledge of WiFi packet structure

doppler_signatures.csi_spectrograms: strong pulse across entire frequency, similar signatures
doppler_signatures.pwr_spectrograms: varied profiles resembling sinusoidal waves, layout-dependent

novel_aspects: First comprehensive comparison between CSI and PWR systems
Systematic analysis of geometric configuration impact
Comparative Doppler signature analysis across systems

strengths: Novel and important comparative study
Rigorous simultaneous data collection methodology
Comprehensive geometric configuration analysis
Detailed signal processing documentation
Clear identification of complementary system strengths
Practical insights for system selection and design
limitations: Small dataset scale (1,122 samples) inadequate for robust deep learning
Simple CNN classifier doesn't fully exploit system capabilities
Single environment testing limits generalizability
No statistical significance testing or confidence intervals
Low overall accuracy compared to typical HAR standards
Missing fusion system implementation despite identified potential

significance.technical_contribution: High - First comprehensive CSI vs PWR comparison with important insights
significance.practical_impact: Moderate - Provides guidance for system selection but limited by experimental scale
significance.research_advancement: Establishes foundation for understanding WiFi sensing system trade-offs

future_work_recommendations: Large-scale dataset collection across multiple environments
Implementation of advanced deep learning architectures
Development and evaluation of CSI-PWR fusion systems
Cross-domain validation across different hardware platforms
Proper statistical analysis with significance testing

014.title: Pushing the Limits of WiFi Sensing With Low Transmission Rates

reversible_csi_representation.description: Fully reversible CSI-to-image conversion preserving sensing information
reversible_csi_representation.impact: Enables lossless machine learning processing of CSI data

specialized_gan_architecture.description: GAN architecture tailored for RF sensing vs computer vision

antenna_correlation_modeling.description: Correlation-based antenna supplement for occluded antennas

loss_function_design.formula: LG = λ₁L₁ + λadvLadv + λcen log(Lcen + 1) + λsemLsem

rate_adaptation_algorithm.mapping_strategy: Interpolation/downsampling for rates ≥15Hz, cascade processing for <15Hz

window_reshaping.strategy: Extract first/last 2s windows for long actions, fuse with averaging
window_reshaping.performance: Comparable to dedicated long-window models without extra training

meeting_room.performance_retention: Good with 19.4-26.9% improvements over raw data

sensing_communication_tradeoff.communication_impact: High-rate sensing (200+ Hz) reduces WiFi throughput by 40%
sensing_communication_tradeoff.accuracy_degradation: 90% → 60% when dropping from 400 Hz to 50 Hz

conventional_gan.accuracy_improvement: 11.9% better than conventional GAN with RF-specific losses

interpolation_methods.linear_interpolation: Minimal improvement, often worse than raw data at low rates
interpolation_methods.nearest_neighbor: Poor performance at low transmission rates

cross_domain_evaluation.cross_environment: Laboratory → Meeting room accuracy drops but remains practical
cross_domain_evaluation.different_models: Effective with CNN, LSTM, RandomForest classifiers

breakthrough_aspects: First systematic study of WiFi sensing-communication co-existence
Novel reversible CSI representation preserving sensing information
Specialized GAN architecture for RF sensing applications
Strategic multi-rate training reducing computational overhead by 90%

limitations: Single-user scenarios only, multi-person sensing challenging
Limited activity diversity, complex fine-grained motions need investigation
Environmental adaptation shows accuracy drops across domains
Hardware dependency on Intel 5300, broader compatibility needed
future_directions: Multi-person sensing with spatial separation techniques
Real-time optimization with online learning adaptation
Background traffic robustness in practical deployments
Cross-hardware generalization across diverse WiFi platforms

immediate_applications: Smart home deployment without communication interference
Industrial IoT sensing with existing WiFi infrastructure
long_term_significance: Foundation for sensing-communication co-design in future wireless systems
Demonstrates viability of specialized AI for wireless sensing

strengths: Addresses fundamental deployment barrier in WiFi sensing
Novel specialized AI architecture for RF applications
Comprehensive multi-application experimental validation
Immediate practical impact with broad applicability
Strong theoretical foundation with practical implementation

domain_adaptation_framework.innovation: Transfer learning for WiFi sensing generalization

017.title: Energy-Efficient WiFi Sensing with Dynamic Power Management and Intelligent Duty Cycling
017.venue: ACM Transactions on Embedded Computing Systems (TECS) 2024
017.abstract: Energy-efficient WiFi sensing system using dynamic power management and intelligent duty cycling achieving 83% power reduction while maintaining 96% activity recognition accuracy

dynamic_power_model.formula: P_total(t) = P_rf(t) + P_proc(t) + P_idle(t), P_rf(t) = α × f_sample(t) + β × BW(t) + γ × TX_power(t)
dynamic_power_model.description: Dynamic power consumption model with RF, processing, and idle power components

duty_cycling_optimization.formula: δ_optimal = arg min Σ_t [P_total(t) × δ(t)] subject to R_accuracy ≥ R_target, L_latency ≤ L_max
duty_cycling_optimization.description: Optimal duty cycle selection balancing power consumption with performance constraints

predictive_scheduling.formula: S(t+Δt) = LSTM(S(t-w:t), C(t), P_history), Power_budget(t+Δt) = f_allocation(S(t+Δt), E_remaining(t))
predictive_scheduling.description: LSTM-based predictive activity-aware power allocation and scheduling

adaptive_sampling_algorithm.innovation: Context-aware CSI sampling frequency optimization based on activity detection

hierarchical_sleep_wake.innovation: Multi-level power management with nested sleep states and predictive wake-up

quality_aware_compression.innovation: Adaptive feature selection based on available power budget
quality_aware_compression.accuracy_impact: <2% accuracy loss in low power mode

innovation_ratings.theory_justification: Novel mathematical framework for joint power optimization and activity recognition with formal optimization theory
innovation_ratings.method_justification: First comprehensive energy-efficient WiFi sensing framework with predictive duty cycling and adaptive sampling
innovation_ratings.system_justification: Complete energy-efficient system achieving 83% power reduction with 8-month real-world validation

editorial_appeal.importance_justification: Addresses fundamental deployment barrier enabling battery-powered WiFi sensing in practical scenarios
editorial_appeal.rigor_justification: 8-month real-world deployment with comprehensive energy analysis and battery-powered testing validation
editorial_appeal.innovation_justification: Significant methodological innovations in power management adapted specifically for WiFi sensing
editorial_appeal.impact_justification: Enables practical battery-powered deployment with week-long operation unlocking numerous applications

introduction_section.content: Energy efficiency as critical requirement for practical WiFi sensing deployment

methods_section.content: Intelligent duty cycling and dynamic power management algorithms

results_section.content: Comprehensive energy efficiency validation and long-term deployment results

discussion_section.content: Energy-efficient sensing implications for practical deployment scenarios

limitations: Activity prediction dependency leading to suboptimal power allocation when predictions fail
Hardware-specific optimization requiring calibration for different WiFi chipsets
Limited multi-user scenario analysis affecting concurrent sensing applications
Sleep-wake transition overhead potentially affecting real-time sensing requirements
Battery aging considerations beyond 8-month validation period not extensively analyzed
strengths: Comprehensive energy optimization addressing critical practical deployment barrier
Rigorous 8-month real-world deployment validation demonstrating sustained efficiency
Practical implementation achieving 83% power reduction with 96% accuracy maintenance
Adaptive power management dynamically balancing energy and performance requirements
Long-term deployment validation proving sustained battery-powered operation
017.classification_justification: Significant practical contributions addressing energy efficiency challenges through innovative power management achieving demonstrated 83% power reduction

bibliographic_data.title: Domain Adaptation Theory for Cross-Environment WiFi Sensing: Mathematical Foundations and Convergence Analysis

equations: ∃ f_universal: X → Y such that ∀D_i, D_j: P(T_i) = P(T_j)
algorithms: Unified domain adaptation framework with formal domain and task definitions
H-divergence and MMD-based domain distance measurement with convergence guarantees
Adversarial domain adaptation with theoretical convergence analysis and error bounds
MMD-based domain alignment with generalization bounds and sample complexity analysis
Multi-environment generalization framework with diversity measures and robustness analysis
Environmental parameterization and continuous mapping theory for robustness quantification
theoretical_contributions: First comprehensive mathematical theory for cross-environment WiFi sensing domain adaptation
Unified framework integrating multiple divergence measures with convergence guarantees
Theoretical error bounds and generalization analysis for domain adaptation algorithms
Environmental parameterization theory with continuous mapping and robustness analysis
Multi-environment learning framework with diversity measures and sample complexity bounds
Computational complexity analysis and performance prediction theory for domain adaptation

breakthrough_points: First complete mathematical theory framework for WiFi sensing cross-environment domain adaptation
Unified analysis integrating H-divergence, MMD, and Wasserstein distance measures with theoretical guarantees
Comprehensive convergence analysis for adversarial and MMD-based domain adaptation algorithms
Environmental parameterization and robustness theory enabling quantitative environment adaptation analysis
Theoretical performance prediction framework achieving <6% error in cross-domain accuracy prediction

complexity_theory_validation.mmd_complexity_match: 96.2% measured compliance with O(n_s n_t d)
complexity_theory_validation.adversarial_complexity_match: 94.7% measured compliance with O(n_s d² T_adv)

theoretical_evaluation: Comprehensive mathematical framework validation with theory-practice gap <5% across all major bounds
Algorithm convergence theory validation with 95.2% adversarial and 89.4% MMD convergence satisfaction
Performance prediction model validation achieving <6% error for 28/35 domain adaptation papers
Environmental adaptation theory validation with 93.5% robustness radius theory-experiment consistency
Computational complexity theory validation with >90% compliance across all major algorithm classes

specific_applications: Unified domain adaptation theoretical framework for systematic DFHAR cross-environment algorithm analysis
Mathematical convergence guarantees and error bounds for rigorous DFHAR domain adaptation evaluation
Performance prediction models for DFHAR deployment risk assessment and algorithm selection guidance
Environmental parameterization theory for quantitative DFHAR system robustness and adaptation analysis
Computational complexity theory for DFHAR algorithm efficiency analysis and resource planning optimization

trend_analysis.research_direction: Mathematical foundations for cross-environment WiFi sensing domain adaptation

strengths: First comprehensive mathematical theory framework for cross-environment WiFi sensing domain adaptation
Rigorous theoretical analysis with complete definition-theorem-proof system and convergence guarantees
Unified framework integrating multiple divergence measures (H-divergence, MMD, Wasserstein distance)
Theoretical performance prediction capability with <6% error in practical algorithm performance
Environmental parameterization and robustness theory enabling quantitative adaptation analysis
Comprehensive computational complexity analysis providing algorithm selection and resource planning guidance
limitations: Real-time adaptation theory insufficient for online learning and dynamic environment scenarios
Privacy-preserving domain adaptation theory integration limited for federated learning applications
Theory-practice gap requires additional validation in complex real-world deployment scenarios
Computational complexity of certain theoretically optimal algorithms may limit practical applicability
Environmental modeling assumptions may not capture all complex factors in practical deployments
Multi-source domain adaptation theory needs further development for complex fusion scenarios
future_directions: Development of real-time and online domain adaptation mathematical theory and convergence analysis
Integration of privacy-preserving mechanisms with domain adaptation theory for federated scenarios
Extension to multi-modal sensor domain adaptation with unified theoretical framework
Meta-learning guided adaptive domain adaptation theory for intelligent environment adaptation
Cross-modal domain adaptation theory for sensor-vision-wireless sensing unified frameworks
Continuous domain adaptation theory for dynamically changing environments and concept drift

034.title: A Taxonomy of WiFi Sensing: CSI vs Passive WiFi Radar
034.domain: Device-Free Human Activity Recognition (DFHAR), WiFi Sensing, Comparative Analysis

Comprehensive WiFi sensing system taxonomy framework
Geometry-dependent performance insights for practical deployment
key_algorithms: CSI processing: DWT denoising + PCA + STFT
CLEAN algorithm for direct signal cancellation
Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) for noise reduction
strengths: First comprehensive comparison between CSI and PWR systems
Rigorous synchronized dual-system measurement methodology
Multi-geometric configuration analysis
Detailed working mechanism explanations
Clear practical deployment guidelines
Comprehensive activity class evaluation
limitations: Limited to six activity classes
Controlled indoor environment only
Small participant group (5 volunteers)
Both systems achieve <70% combined accuracy
Limited computational complexity analysis
No hybrid system evaluation

csi_characteristics: Strong pulses across entire frequency range

key_insights: PWR performs better in bistatic/monostatic setups
Both systems achieve similar overall accuracy
Walking activity achieves highest recognition rates
Hybrid approaches could leverage complementary strengths

impact_assessment.long_term_significance: High - foundation for hybrid sensing systems

Partial adaptation with selective feature transfer

Bayesian inference for WiFi sensing reliability

Confidence-aware decision making in wireless sensing systems

strengths: Pioneering integration of uncertainty quantification with cross-environment WiFi sensing
Comprehensive WiCAU architecture with principled Bayesian uncertainty estimation
Exceptional cross-environment performance (91.7%) with significant improvements over baselines

Extension to more complex activities and multi-person scenarios

Meta-learning approaches for fast adaptation to novel environments

bibliographic_data.title: AutoFi: Towards Automatic WiFi Human Sensing via Geometric Self-Supervised Learning
bibliographic_data.venue: Proceedings of the ACM on Interactive, Mobile, Wearable and Ubiquitous Technologies

algorithms: Geometric self-supervised learning framework
Multi-view geometric feature extraction (spatial-temporal-frequency)
Contrastive learning with geometric data augmentation
Lie group theory-based geometric invariance
Manifold learning for CSI data modeling
theoretical_contributions: First geometric deep learning theory for WiFi human sensing
Geometric invariance framework based on Lie group theory
Multi-view geometric feature extraction mathematical foundation
Zero-annotation learning paradigm for WiFi sensing automation

breakthrough_points: First geometric self-supervised learning framework eliminating annotation requirements for WiFi sensing
Multi-view geometric feature extraction combining spatial-temporal-frequency perspectives
91.3% zero-annotation performance (+1.6% vs fully supervised with 10K labels)
31.2% improvement in 1-shot learning and <2% performance drop under geometric transformations

datasets_used: Multi-environment WiFi sensing dataset with CSI N×M×T configuration
Geometric augmentation with ±15° rotation and ±10% scale variations
Temperature parameter τ=0.07 for contrastive learning optimization
4D geometric space modeling (3D spatial + temporal dimensions)
baseline_comparisons: Supervised learning with 10K labels (89.7% vs 91.3% AutoFi)
Traditional few-shot methods (significant improvements across all shot settings)

specific_applications: Geometric self-supervised learning frameworks for zero-annotation WiFi sensing deployment
Multi-view geometric feature extraction techniques for robust wireless sensing applications
Automatic WiFi sensing systems with geometric invariance and cross-environment generalization
Self-supervised pretraining strategies for efficient WiFi sensing model development

strengths: Pioneering geometric self-supervised learning framework eliminating WiFi sensing annotation requirements
Outstanding zero-annotation performance (91.3%) exceeding fully supervised methods with 10K labels
Exceptional few-shot learning capabilities with 31.2% improvement in 1-shot scenarios
Strong geometric invariance with <2% performance degradation under spatial transformations
Comprehensive theoretical foundation based on Lie group theory and manifold learning
Significant training efficiency improvement (12 hours vs 48 hours traditional approaches)
limitations: Geometric invariance assumptions may fail in complex multipath environments
High computational overhead from geometric transformations and contrastive learning (4096 negative samples)
WiFi signal nonlinear propagation characteristics not fully considered in geometric modeling
Performance dependence on geometric structure assumptions limiting extreme environment adaptability
Contrastive learning negative sampling strategies have limited adaptation to diverse environments
Temperature parameter τ optimization requires task and environment-specific tuning
future_directions: Lightweight geometric transformation algorithms for reduced computational complexity
Adaptive negative sampling strategies for improved contrastive learning across environments
Environment-aware geometric invariance dynamic adjustment mechanisms
Multi-modal geometric learning integration (WiFi+vision+audio)
Online geometric feature updating and adaptation frameworks
Causal geometric learning theory for enhanced interpretability

wifi_har_relevance.methodological_contribution: Geometric self-supervised learning framework for automated WiFi sensing without annotation requirements

adaptation_requirements: Geometric self-supervised pretraining pipelines for WiFi sensing automation

trend_analysis.research_direction: Cross-environment WiFi sensing with zero-target domain adaptation

strengths: First systematic domain generalization framework providing comprehensive mathematical modeling for WiFi gesture recognition
Outstanding cross-domain performance (89-92%) with significant 15-27% improvement over existing methods
Zero-target domain data requirement dramatically simplifying practical deployment scenarios
Rigorous RKHS mathematical foundation with MMD theory and adversarial learning integration
Comprehensive experimental validation across 4 environments with statistical significance testing
Strong theoretical convergence guarantees and performance bounds analysis
limitations: MMD theory assumes source and target domain feature space isomorphism, which may break under extreme environmental changes
Computational complexity O(n²) for MMD calculation poses scalability challenges for large-scale deployment
Limited evaluation to 4 indoor environments, lacking outdoor and complex industrial environment validation
Adversarial training convergence stability may face challenges in practical deployment scenarios
Feature disentanglement dimension allocation requires significant domain expertise and parameter tuning
Performance degradation when environmental differences exceed training domain distribution coverage
future_directions: Non-parametric domain generalization theory development reducing kernel function selection dependency
Multi-source domain joint learning frameworks integrating complementary information from multiple source domains

89.2% cross-domain accuracy with 12.9% improvement over baseline methods

trend_analysis.research_direction: Cross-domain WiFi sensing with style transfer enhancement and distributed collaboration

strengths: First systematic application of neural style transfer theory providing comprehensive framework for WiFi sensing domain generalization
Outstanding cross-domain performance (89.2%) with significant 12.9% improvement over state-of-the-art domain adaptation methods
Innovative distributed collaborative sensing architecture with dynamic load balancing and communication optimization
Strong theoretical foundation with Gram matrix style representation and PAC-Bayesian convergence analysis
Practical deployment value with 80% retraining reduction and system scalability for large-scale WiFi networks
Comprehensive experimental validation across 6 environments with rigorous statistical significance testing
limitations: Gram matrix assumption of feature independence may not hold for complex spatiotemporal WiFi CSI correlations
Style randomization may disrupt physical constraints and causal relationships in WiFi signals
High computational complexity O(d²) of Gram matrix calculation limiting real-time applications
Communication overhead (0.88MB/s) requiring sustained bandwidth may be challenging in practical network conditions
Device synchronization and data consistency challenges in large-scale distributed deployment scenarios
Limited evaluation of system robustness under device failures and dynamic network topology changes
future_directions: Physics-aware style randomization methods preserving WiFi signal physical meaning and electromagnetic constraints
Non-Gaussian noise models for style enhancement adapting to complex electromagnetic environments
Lightweight Gram matrix approximation algorithms reducing real-time computational complexity
Edge-cloud hierarchical collaborative architecture minimizing communication overhead
Federated learning framework integration for privacy-preserving distributed style enhancement
6G sensing-communication integration with native distributed optimization support
